CIRCUIT COURT OF
TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
PATRICK CRADDOCK, CLERK
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF TALLAPOOSA COUNTY, ALABAMA
ALEXANDER CITY DIVISION
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR )
PLAINTIFF/RESPONDENT )
)
VS. ) CASE NO. DR-2023-900051.01
)
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND )
DEFENDANT/PETITIONER )
AMENDMENT TO COUNTERPETITION FOR CONTEMPT
Comes now the Plaintiff/Father, Christopher Baline McGregor, by and through his
attorney of record, Dianne James Davis, and realleges all allegations contained in his previously
filed Counterpetition for Contempt and would further show the Court the following:
COUNT II
MODIFICATION OF VISITATION
1) That pursuant to the Temporary Order entered by this Honorable Court on the 14th
day of April, 2025, the Defendant/Mother was granted visitation with the minor
child, B.M. (DOB: 05/10/2019), every other weekend from Friday after school
until Monday morning, at which time the child was to be returned to school or to
the Father.
2) That pursuant to the Court’s Final Decree of Divorce entered on the 27th day of
February, 2024, the Mother was awarded certain visitation periods with both
minor children, including the 1st and 3rd full weeks of June and July.
3) That for some time, the minor child, A.K.M. (DOB: 05/24/2012), has not
exercised visitation with the Defendant/Mother due to emotional or relational
issues she has experienced with her mother. Furthermore, at a prior hearing, the
Court ordered that visitation between A.K.M. and the Defendant/Mother would be
suspended pending counseling for the child. Due to A.K.M.’s age, the Father
requests that she be allowed to visit the Mother at her own discretion.
DOCUMENT 202
4) That several months ago, the Mother relocated to Clanton, Chilton County,
Alabama. The travel time between the Mother’s new residence and Alexander
City is approximately 1.15 hours.
5) That as a result of the relocation, the minor child, B.M., is now required to travel
between Alexander City and Clanton every other weekend, which is
approximately a 2.30-hour drive round trip. During summer and holiday
visitation periods, both children are subject to the same travel demands.
6) That the frequent travel, particularly on alternating weekends, has become
increasingly burdensome on the minor child, B.M., and is no longer in his best
interest.
7) That the Father asserts a modification of the current visitation schedule is
warranted in light of the Mother’s relocation in order to reduce the strain on the
minor child and to promote his stability and well-being.
WHEREFORE, PREMISES CONSIDERED, the Plaintiff/Father respectfully requests
that this Honorable Court modify the Defendant/Mother’s visitation schedule to account for the
increased travel demands resulting from her relocation and to serve the best interest of the minor
child, B.M. Plaintiff/Father further requests that the minor child, A.K.M., be allowed to visit
with the Mother at her own discretion. The Plaintiff/Father requests all such other relief to
which he may be entitled, the premises considered.
Respectfully submitted this the 27th day of June, 2025.
/s/Dianne James Davis
Dianne James Davis (DAV007)
Attorney for Plaintiff/Father
107 Main Street
Alexander City, AL 35010
(256) 392-3172
(256) 392-3578 (facsimile)
dianne@diannedavislaw.com
DOCUMENT 202
Certificate of Service
I hereby certify that I have served a copy of the foregoing upon the following via
electronic filing with the AlaCourt E-File System and/or by placing a copy of the same, properly
addressed and postage paid in the U.S. Mail on this the 27th day of June, 2025.
Barbara H. Agricola
127 South 8th Street
Opelika, AL 36801
/s/Dianne James Davis
Of Counsel
